metadata.case_name: R. S. Sial v. State of Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: Appellant appointed Traffic Manager in the transport organization of the State of Uttar Pradesh on July 21, 1948.
Office of Traffic Manager subsequently designated as Assistant General Manager and appellant continued to work as such.
On December 1, 1955, appellant confirmed as Assistant General Manager with effect from April 1, 1955.
On July 5, 1963, appellant appointed Officiating General Manager in the Gorakhpur region of the Transport Department.
Appellant continued to officiate as General Manager of Government Roadways till September 7, 1967.
On September 7, 1967, appellant reverted to the post of Assistant General Manager by order No. 714/PAVS/67 dated September 7, 1967.
Appellant filed writ petition No. 3167 of 1967 challenging reversion, summarily dismissed by Division Bench on September 12, 1967.
Representation made by appellant against reversion order, rejected by State Government on October 7, 1968.
Appellant filed writ petition No. 1073 of 1968 under Article 226 praying for quashing reversion order and rejection of representation.
High Court dismissed writ petition: barred by earlier dismissal and on merits reversion not punitive as appellant only officiating.
Letter dated July 12, 1967 from Deputy Secretary, Vigilance to Director of Vigilance requesting open enquiry into allegations of appellant's involvement in supply of non-genuine motor parts.
Letter dated July 12, 1967 from Deputy Secretary, Vigilance to Secretary, Transport Dept. requesting reversion if not confirmed, as CID enquiry revealed substance in corruption allegations.
Affidavit of Shri Bhagwan Sarup Saxena, Deputy Secretary, in opposition stating appellant merely officiating, no right to post.

legal_issues.text: Whether the present petition was barred by dismissal of earlier writ petition No. 3167 of 1967.
Whether the order of reversion from Officiating General Manager to Assistant General Manager was by way of punishment requiring compliance with Article 311 of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Previous petition No. 3167 of 1967 dismissed summarily by non-speaking order, not on merits, so present petition not barred.
Reversion was by way of punishment without complying with Article 311, liable to be quashed.

respondent_arguments.text: Present petition barred by dismissal of earlier petition.
Appellant merely officiating as General Manager, no right to post, could be reverted to substantive post of Assistant General Manager without disciplinary action or reasons.

court_reasoning.text: Not necessary to decide res judicata as reversion order not by way of punishment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order contains no adverse remarks or stigma; appellant's substantive post was Assistant General Manager.

court_reasoning.text: Officiating appointment transitory, terminable at any time absent contract or rule; no vested right unless entails forfeiture of pay, loss of seniority etc.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reversion to substantive post without stigma does not attract Article 311.

court_reasoning.text: Test: whether misconduct foundation or mere motive; here vigilance letters show motive for reversion pending enquiry, not foundation; motive immaterial if right to revert exists.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Vigilance letters indicate pending enquiry provided motive, not punishment.

court_reasoning.text: Application for additional documents rejected as they existed earlier and not necessary.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Documents traceable earlier, not needed for judgment.

holdings.text: Order of reversion not by way of punishment; does not attract Article 311.

precedents_cited.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Officiating servants protected under Art 311 if punishment; test for penalty in termination/reversion.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. Gajendra Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Indicators of penalty like loss of pay/seniority.

precedents_cited.case_name: Champaklal Chimanlal Shah v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Protection under Art 311 for officiating if punishment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Apar Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Protection under Art 311 for officiating if punishment.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bihar v. Shiva Bhikshuk Mishra
precedents_cited.relevance: Test: misconduct motive or foundation of order.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Punjab v. Shri Sukh Rai Bahadur
precedents_cited.relevance: Propositions on termination of temporary/probationer not attracting Art 311 unless stigma or full enquiry.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. R. S. Dhabal
precedents_cited.relevance: Motive immaterial if right to terminate/revert exists.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition under 226; protection against punitive reversion without compliance under 311.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed as reversion not punitive; High Court order upheld. Application for additional documents rejected.

key_quotes.text: "the order of reversion of the appellant cannot be said to have been made by way of punishment."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Appointment to a post on an officiating basis is, from the nature of employment, itself of a transitory character and ... terminable at any time."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains legal nature of officiating post.

key_quotes.text: "The test for attracting article 311(2) ... is whether the misconduct ... is a mere motive ... or ... the very foundation."
key_quotes.speaker: court
